poem:
**A Coal-Trimmer's Testament**

In the belly of iron giants,  
sweat and soot blend over bones;  
Jimmy, a shadow in the furnace glow—  
lungs drinking fire, heart beating  
like the cold ocean's whisper.  
To the stern end, with steel spirit,  
to taste the salt of fate,  
and hear the Titanic's last breath.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It was filthy, horrible work’: actors Paul and Stephen McGann reveal how their great uncle survived the Titanic Clinging to an overturned raft in the perilous, frozen waters of the north Atlantic, Jimmy McGann witnessed the horror of the 1912 sinking of the Titanic. He was one of its soot-covered coal-trimmers, toiling in blazing heat, shovelling coal into furnaces that powered the mighty vessel. Jimmy stayed aboard with the captain until the ship’s last moments". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
